subject: dbus-sdr: Add sensor mutability
commitMessage:
dbus-sdr: Add sensor mutability

Sensor ValueMutability interface has already been merged into
openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces here:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/36333

This change adds the IPMI server-side changes, namely, the test for
the "Mutable" member of this interface existing and being "true".
If so, it grants external write permission to this sensor, otherwise,
it will remain read-only (which is the default).

It replaces a previous compile-time constant that could only be changed
at compilation time, and would affect all sensors globally, neither of
which was desirable.

This "Mutable" interface boolean can be used to grant write
permission to sensors, such as external sensors and fan PWM sensors in
manual mode. IPMI setting sensor reading will check the mutability
first.

It achieves feature parity with the old
"mutability: Mutability::Write|Mutability::Read" settings,
in the old hardcoded YAML configuration files.

Also see the dbus-sensors changes, namely, the reading of this
parameter from entity-manager configuration, and setting
this D-Bus property accordingly, if "Mutable" is true:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/45405

Tested: With both 45405 and 45407 changes in, this feature has been
working nicely in our local environment for some time now.

Signed-off-by: Jie Yang <jjy@google.com>
Change-Id: I4ecff1a0424c0bc23d3a90466e1bb4b655f07859
Signed-off-by: Josh Lehan <krellan@google.com>

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as f0a89946f1e3ce2e8fe97525e6b057463aa2a169 by Jie Yang
How does this change make this possible?

In manual mode, the IPMI user is expected to provide manual values. By marking the sensors as read-write permissions, instead of the default of read-only permissions, this now becomes possible from the IPMI client. The IPMI SDR has this permissions as Bit 7 of Byte 11 of Table 43.2 of the IPMI spec.

Here's how to set fans between auto and manual mode:

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-pid-control/blob/master/ipmi.md

This is already supported by phosphor-pid-control module. After you issue this OEM command to set the fan to manual mode, then you can change the fan PWM sensor value by issuing the standard IPMI "Set Sensor Reading" command, as per section 35.17 of the IPMI spec.

https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/products/docs/servers/ipmi/ipmi-second-gen-interface-spec-v2-rev1-1.html

Although the above text is IPMI-specific, equivalent Redfish functionality is expected to be provided soon. The Mutable feature is generic enough to work with both IPMI and Redfish, provided appropriate implementations exist.

We wanna use dbus-sdr with dbus-sensor, but we do not include some intel oem commands like manufacturing mode stuff. Briefly speaking, in our use case, the ValueMutability interface implemented in dbus-sensor will tell us if the sensor value is settable (mutable). Then IPMI setting sensor command will check the sensor mutability.
So "Manual Mode" is referring to phosphor-pid-controls's oem command, it disables the automatic pid control of fans. But it is not a PwmSensor(dbus-sensors) mode.
remove this flag with we are using Mutable flag to control the sensor write permission.

*when we are using Mutable flag...

----

but anyway, this will include some changes in config.ac
Done

this is only called in getSensor handlers.

This will force the set handler to be dependent on the get handler. Ideally each handler shoul dbe independent of each other.

I would suggest also checking the `Mutable` flag the first time in the set handler

It is intentional that set sensor reading depends on getting sensor SDR IIUC. IPMI users are supposed to fetch the sensor SDR first and then optionally setting sensor value with write permission. 

Every time users call ipmi getSensorSdr, the sdrWriteTable will be refreshed, as the sensor stack is dynamically collected from dbus-sensor.

Hao, do you have any comment on this?

I remember that we had a discussion on this topic internally.

It is definitely a bug, that the set-handler code path doesn't initialize the SDR in the same way as the get-handler code path. Ideally, these two code paths should be equivalent.

However, fixing this bug is beyond the scope of the Mutable feature, I feel. It should be the subject of a second patch, as it would be making a much deeper change.

As long as the existing behavior is erring on the side of caution, denying the IPMI write attempt if the SDR permission can't be verified to allow external mutability, then I'm OK with accepting this patch as-is.
This code has been running downstream for a while. getting SDR will construct a sensor:write-permission table. IPMI set sensor value command checks the write permission from the table.

That is correct. Getting the SDR will construct the write permission table normally. However, the concern was if the user attempts a "set value" command without getting the SDR first or performing a "get value" command first. In other words, if the user blindly sends a "set value" command, bad things will happen. However, this is a topic for another patch, not here.

Query : Wanted to know advantage of using inline here ..?

nit:
Could we have made this as part of IPMIStatsTable ?

IPMIStatsTable is an optional feature, that is only beneficial for debugging/troubleshooting purposes, and can be compiled out if desired, to save space, without any user-visible change in functionality. That's why it was separate. IPMIWriteTable is more important, though, and stores the mutability permissions of each sensor.

It solves a circular dependency regarding variable declarations and definitions, with headers that can include others, such as what is done by many users of these headers. Basically, in some situations this header would be included twice, which would cause a compilation error if this were not done. https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/inline
just one query s, if header guard is present in header file then is it required to add inline ..?

Yes, it's still required. Header guards protect, against multiple inclusion, only during the preprocessor. Adding 'inline" to variable declarations protect during compilation and linking as well. This is important for programs that include this header multiple times from different modules that are then linked together.
